text: Batch 4. Pours a hazy golden yellow from the bottle with bubbly white head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma is loads of funk and acidity with hints of wheat and floral undertones. Taste is the closest thing I have had to a Belgian style lambic from an American brewery, loads of mild funk, a hint of light fruit, oaky must, mild acidity. Wow, this was a big surprise, gonna have to keep an eye out for more of their beer.

750 ml Bottle. Batch 4. The beer is a hazy gold with a fizzy white head of foam that dissipates quickly. Almost no head retention. The aroma has big lactic sourness. Some doughy, bready, funky tartness in the taste. Some moderate herbal notes. Subtle though. Sour and lactic throughout. Lighter in body and medium carbonation. Spritzy mouthfeel.

Several oz. pour from a bottle; thanks to falco242. Consumed on 8-30-16. A few months under one year of age on this. Pours a hazy yellow with a small amount of short-lasting, beige head. Chamomile scent. Prototypical Berliner Weiss aroma. Nice lemon and white vinegar tartness in flavor. I do get the ginger as well. Very sour in flavor. Really good Berliner Weiss taste. Light to medium body. Frothy in the palate. Quite complex for a non-barrel-aged sour.
Shared bottle at Craft. Hazy gold with white head. Nose was yeasty funk, lemongrassy hops. Some spice in the flavor, lemongrass, hops, ginger, all works well for me.

Funky, barn aroma. Slightly cloudy and almost looks almost like a chard. Wonderful tart flavor with the chamomile coming thru in the palate. The lemon helps with the tartness, too. And the finish is sour but crisp. OEC never disappoints.

750ml bottle pours a clear gold with some creamy, white head. Nose has lemon, butter, a little diaper/baby powder, passion fruit, a little peach. Flavor is very lemony, passion fruit too, apricot, light urine, white grape. Finishes a touch oily. That lemon balm really comes through.
Pours a milky gold with no head. Aroma of lacto, oak and spices. Taste is sour, oak, spices and wheat. Very sour but I like it.

draft offering at the source..this was first up and after this one I knew that this place was legit for sure..nose is unreal..everything a true white wild ale wishes it could be..easily the best take on a white belgian style I have tried to date..this has it all light bodied..yet full of complexity..juicy characteristics..lemon tart and lemon peels abound..getting some of the ginger spice but kept in check..finishes nice and the lactobaccilus is extremely well done..great offering from a place that is doing some very impressive things...

Bottle at James for his 11k tasting. Pours a hazed gold with a thin white head. Musk and lemon and herbs on the nose. Medium bodied, tart acid, soft and funky. Light wood, tart, acid, lingering funk. Tangy.

LSAT Freedom Trip #149. Keg at the brewery. Hazy orange, thin fizzy off-white head, decent retention. Aroma of tart bright lemon, wheat, lacto. The taste is wheat, spice, lemon, chamomile, ginger. Medium bodied, mild lingering tartness.

Bottle shared in NH. Pours a clear pale yellow, thin white head tiny bubbles. Aroma is slices, clove, lemon peel, hay, barnyard, ginger. Flavor is dry, bread, lacto, ginger, spices, floral notes. Med sour, dry, lasting funk.

Batch 2. Bottle picked up at the brewery and shared in NH. It pours hazy gold with a quickly dissipating white head. The nose is soft, fresh, lactic twang, chamomile, white grape, elderflower and a rough of ginger. The taste is crisp, tart, some acidity, white grape, floral, white wine, gooseberry and some cloudy ginger beer. Medium body and fine carbonation. Plenty of white wine feel about it. Rather nice stuff.

Bottle shared in NH. Pours hazy yellow with a foamy white head. The nose has some tangy citrus, lemon, herbal notes. Light sweet flavor with moderate acidity, some hay, lemon rind, some herbs. Light to medium bodied with fine carbonation. Tart finish with cleansing acidity, more lemon. Tasty stuff.
Sampled at the brewery, 9/19/15. Cloudy good color, nice funky aroma and flavor, ginger, other spices, wheat. Finishes clean and tart. Medium body. Very drinkable.
Bottle thanks to Jordan - Pours yellow gold white head. Nose/taste of chamomile, lemon, ginger root and wine/oak - medium body.
Bottle. Hazy golden pour with white head. Herbal, citrus, grassy, spice and funky aromas. Flavors funky citrus, herbal and spice, white tones.

Draught at the brewery, SourFest 8/15/15.Lovely bright white golden body with lemonskin tints and a small but fairly creamy white head.Good blend of malts and soft spicing in the nose, without any heavy lactic acidity. Not a sour ale, per se, but rather just an old style wit, most of which probably had a healthy dose of bacteria in them. Otherwise, lemony-citrus notes give a good acidity as very light ginger and honey balance. Sponge cake, light dough and a fresh, but not overdone herbal finish replete with just a shot of cheesiness. No alcohol, no flaws.Light and fluffy in the mouth, with ample carbonation, well-attenuated but still soft maltiness and a variety of honey, wheat, very mild ginger and light yogurt on the end. Incredibly drinkable and quite mild/reserved for all the things that are added. I really like that these guys seem just as adept at making barrel-aged, wild yeast-laden sour blends as they do at making lighter, playful, drinkable session ales. Tough to say whether Id use this or Exilis as the go-to session beer as both are exquisite. Sadly, I dont have to make that decision since I dont live close.

Growler filled two days ago at the Brewery. Pour has a straw golden color with a ring on the glass of white head. Aroma has tart wheat, herbs, light ginger, yeast, and pokes of flowers. Mouth feel is medium and has low side carbonation. Flavor is absolutely fantastic, mild tartness, sour wheat, citrus touches, flowers, mild ginger, and some light tea in the finish. I was expecting some kind of a white/wit style beer but this is pleasantly tart with a fantastic gentile addition of ginger, tea, and wet herbs. Very complex, lots of layers, has the flowery white ale thing, and a complementing yeastiness. So drinkable and all the pieces fit perfectly!
growler, boom, this is awesome. like florence. Very complex yeast flavors, good bretty characteristics, this is awesome.

Wow, I love this beer. Aroma is mild spices, lemon, tea, clove, and tartness is evident. Taste is tart with mild sweetness with a great creamy mouthfeel. Probably my favorite beer by these guys. Lets put this in wine barrels STAT!

750ml growler in a tulip. Pours hazy golden with a lacy, white head. Aroma of sourness/tartness, pale malts, light citrus and spicy notes, hints of ginger, and some light floral notes. Flavor the same with a cool blend of the sourness and a witbier. Average texture. A solid beer.
